description:
Dysidea avara is a species of marine sponge that belongs to the phylum Porifera. It is commonly known as the avara sponge or the brown encrusting sponge. Dysidea avara is found in tropical and subtropical marine environments, typically in shallow waters near coral reefs or rocky substrates.

The sponge has a flat, encrusting growth form and can reach up to several centimeters in diameter. Its surface is smooth and often has a reddish-brown or dark brown coloration. The sponge's body is composed of a network of interconnected channels and chambers, which are inhabited by specialized cells called choanocytes that are responsible for water filtration and nutrient absorption.

Dysidea avara is known to produce a variety of secondary metabolites, some of which have been found to possess bioactive properties, such as anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and antitumor activities. These compounds have attracted interest from the pharmaceutical and biotechnology industries, as they may have potential applications in the development of new drugs or other products.

The species is an important component of the coral reef ecosystem, serving as a food source for various marine organisms and providing shelter and habitat for a diverse array of associated fauna.
